results.title: Live Updates on George Floyd Protests: A Push For Accountability
results.abstract: As outrage over George Floyd’s death coalesces into a national movement, cities start to heed calls to “defund the police” and lawmakers push proposals for greater accountability. National Guard troops are being sent home from Washington.

results.title: De Blasio Vows for First Time to Cut Funding for the N.Y.P.D.
results.abstract: The mayor made his pledge following 10 nights of mass protests against police violence and mounting demands for an overhaul of the police department.

results.title: In Minneapolis, Somali-Americans Find Unwelcome Echoes of Strife at Home

results.title: The 2 Lawyers, the Anti-Police Protests and the Molotov Cocktail Attack

results.title: ‘Corporate America Has Failed Black America’
results.abstract: For a group of elite black executives, police killings and protests have unleashed an outpouring of emotion and calls for action.

results.title: Vote for Trump? These Republican Leaders Aren’t on the Bandwagon
results.abstract: Former President George W. Bush and Senator Mitt Romney won’t support Mr. Trump’s re-election. Colin Powell will vote for Joe Biden, and other G.O.P. officials may do the same.

results.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Farmers Get Billions in Aid
results.abstract: Democrats are wary as the Trump administration distributes at least $16 billion in agriculture subsidies. New York City will enter its first phase of restarting businesses on Monday, as protesters rallied for racial justice. In India, cases reach a new high.

results.abstract: A rip in the fabric of the economy won’t be healed easily, and denial of the severity of the crisis won’t solve it.

results.title: First Inklings of Fame
results.abstract: The class of 2020 has no idea what the future holds — and neither do we. Here’s a look back at some icons starting on their paths to renown.
results.byline: By Veronica Chambers and Jennifer Harlan

multimedia.caption: “The fact that I’ve been elected shows a lot of progress,” Obama told The Times. “It’s encouraging.” But, he cautioned, “You have to remember that for every one of me, there are hundreds or thousands of black students with at least equal talent who don’t get a chance.”
multimedia.copyright: Joe Wrinn/Harvard University, via Corbis, via Getty Images

results.title: Robert Northern a.k.a. Brother Ah, Jazz Explorer, Dies at 86
results.abstract: A master of the French horn, Mr. Northern was adept at both classical music and jazz. As a bandleader, he was devoted to what he called “sound awareness.”

multimedia.caption: Robert Northern, known professionally as Brother Ah, outside his home in Washington, D.C., in 2017. He played French horn on some of the most storied orchestral recordings in jazz history.

results.title: A Daughter Is Beheaded, and Iran Asks if Women Have a Right to Safety

results.title: Why Many Athletes Will Be Left Out When Olympic Training Centers Reopen
results.abstract: As the U.S. Olympic Committee tries to navigate a safe reopening of its facilities, there will be tough decisions about who can stay and who must go.
org_facet: United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee

multimedia.caption: The skeleton racer Katie Uhlaender at the 2018 Winter Olympics. She is among the athletes hoping to extend her access to the U.S. Olympic training center in Lake Placid, N.Y.

results.title: China Vowed to Keep Wildlife Off the Menu, a Tough Promise to Keep
results.abstract: The government has moved slowly to permanently stop the sale and consumption of wild animals in the wake of the coronavirus epidemic, raising fears the practice may continue.

multimedia.caption: Workers in protective suits outside the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in Wuhan, China, in March.

results.title: Contact Tracing With Your Phone: It’s Easier but There Are Tradeoffs
results.abstract: Lots of new app ideas are emerging to track Covid-19, but each has issues around privacy, location accuracy and how much appeal it will have to the public and to health officials.

multimedia.caption: A French police officer checked the QR code of a driver in Paris during the nationwide lockdown last month. Technologies like Bluetooth and QR codes could help officials contact-trace, but challenges of privacy and access abound.

results.title: How to Keep Children’s Stress From Turning Into Trauma
results.abstract: Parents can help children use the stress of coronavirus shutdowns as an opportunity for growth, experts say.

results.title: How to Reduce Your Risk of PTSD in a Post-Covid-19 World
results.abstract: It’s normal to feel a sense of hopelessness and loneliness in these times. But there are proven and proactive ways for you to get through it.

results.title: How to Prepare Your Dog to Be Left at Home Alone (Again)
results.abstract: Whether your dog is new or old, these tips will help ease its transition from lockdown to normal life.

results.title: Parents Are Relying on Melatonin to Help Their Kids Sleep. Should They?
results.abstract: A survey suggests that nearly half of children with difficulty sleeping have taken melatonin.

results.title: How to Tell if It’s More Than Just a Bad Mood
results.abstract: It is understandable if the coronavirus pandemic has put you in a funk, but depression should be evaluated and treated.

results.title: Their Wedding Day Was ‘Divinely Appointed’
results.abstract: Melody Thuston and Damion Cowan had to scale down their celebration because of the coronavirus, and when their original officiant couldn’t attend, her father, a bishop, stepped in.

multimedia.caption: Melody Thuston and Damion Cowan met in 2006 at Alabama A&M University. They were married April 25 at Boone Tabernacle Church of God in Christ in Kansas City, Mo. After the ceremony they returned to her parents house to celebrate.

results.title: Two Huge Covid-19 Studies Are Retracted After Scientists Sound Alarms
results.abstract: The reports, published in two leading journals, were retracted after authors could not verify an enormous database of medical records.
results.byline: By Roni Caryn Rabin and Ellen Gabler

multimedia.caption: Two prominent studies on the drugs chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine that used the same dataset from a company called Surgisphere were retracted on Thursday.

results.title: Managing the Majestic Jumbo Flying Squid
